description:
The app now works fine when screen mirroring, but when extending (by selecting "virtual display") the resolution is fixed at 1280x720 and it is not possible to change it.

Note: I use the Microsoft wireless display adapter.
summary: Works fine when mirroring, but resolution is too low when extending

description: It worked out of the box. I had some small issues related to latency (the shared screen was 1-2 seconds behind what I was currently showing) and to the audio not being mirrored, but other than that it worked flawlessly and the connection seemed to be stable.
summary: It worked out of the box

description:
It does what is says it does. While it doesn't work for everything (e.g. devices that require PINs don't work), it works most of the time and when it does, it works very well.

I especially like that you can create a virtual monitor and cast *that*, instead of simply mirroring your main screen. This is a functionality that most screencasting apps don't offer, and is very nice to see.

One big caveat is the design - it's a relic of the early GNOME 3 era, and could definetely use some porting to GTK4/Adwaita. Other than that, it's great.
summary: Works most of the time, but needs some modernisation

description:
The program does find the devices and tries to connect to them, but an empty error message is thrown after 2 mins of connecting.

Sadge.
summary: Does not work with a Galaxy Tab S8+ using second screen

description: Connects to the TV for about 10 seconds, then times out and return to the normal TV screen. I'm keeping it around hoping that a future release will fix this issue. I like what I see for the brief moment that it does work.
It send the petition, I can allow the pettion in my tv, but then the app is loading and keep in that, it says "establishing connection to sink"

This used to crash my WiFi driver, but after the update to Fedora 33 Screen Share is now working. This is a really nice feature, to be able to show a presentation on the television. 
It would be awesome if the delay could be minimized a bit in a further version
summary: Finally works after the upgrade to Fedora 33

description:
Tested it on Kubuntu 21.04 and it works (with LG TV), but:
The performance is really bad, the network is barely used, as the system monitor reports, less than 100 KB/s
Switched wpa_supplicant to iwd for better wifi performance and features and the program dosn't work at all anymore saying that it cannot find any Wifi adapters even though the internet still works and I'm writing this review over that wifi.
The naming is weird having Gnome in it, even though I'm on KDE and it makes the icon name longer than what it should be.
I don't like that it doesn't respect my custom window decorations and it still displays the Gnome ones
summary: Still needs a lot of work !

description:
This app lets me connect to my Microsoft Wireless Display Adapter. Sometimes it fails, but I keep retrying connection and it worked. Would be better if it can show error details without the need to run G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=all in terminal.

I'm using this app with wpa_supplicant and ath10k driver.
summary: Works great most of the time, But error messages need improvements

description: Please dont update to p2p connection. I downloaded from github the latest one, it asked me to p2p connection. So please ..

This app lets me easily select a display from my dual-monitor setup and cast to my Miracast-equipped TV without going though complicated steps. Can be even better/more convenient if the app can switch the audio output device automatically on connecting to/disconnecting from displays without user having to switch manually.
summary: Great for casting to Miracast-powered TV dongle

description: Works great on Fedora 36 casting to a Fire Stick. Thanks!
Can't seem to share my display on this computer with my other computer. This doesn't even let me set a name for this computer's share.
Audio and video worked immediately, syncing a Slimbook running KDE Neon to a Samsung TV on the same WiFi network
summary: Worked immediately to connect KDE Neon laptop to Samsung TV

description: It just doesn't work, gives an error

I'm using Nobara Linux 38 with KDE Desktop on Wayland. This makes connecting a miracast screen a breeze, gives a much higher frame rate, and seems more stable than Windows counterpart. However, I'd need to connect to an external speaker as they need to use X11 frame grabbing instead of Mutter's protocol, and it probably won't grab audio on Wayland. If anyone have a test result on X11 and/or GNOME desktop, please write a review on audio experience there as well. It's help everyone a lot.
Casting of media output (from VLC or brower) to the receiving network display device is interrupted unless the "Network Display" window remains on tops
summary: Casting to TV screen interrupted when "Network Display" not on top

description: So, I've been looking for a way to wirelessly use my TV as a second screen via MiraCast as I did in Windows since switching to Linux. With a little more refinement, I think this could fit the bill. The issue is that it's slow and horrendously laggy, to the point of being completely useless. Fix the transfer speed issues, and you've got it!

I use it to watch movies on my Samsung Tv and it works pretty good, a bit laggy, but somehow expected. 

If you install the flatpak version be aware that you need to install the codecs in the flatpak environment, too, because it won't recognize the one from the system. I've tried the flatpak version, but I couldn't make it work, so I installed the RPM version on Fedora 39 and it worked after that.
Does not find mircast sink of Amazon FireTV
summary: Does not find mircast sink of Amazon FireTV
